items.title: Bernie Sanders demands that RFK Jr step down as health secretary
items.standfirst: Vermont senator says Kennedy is endangering the health of the American people as head of the US health departmentBernie Sanders has joined in on growing public calls for Donald Trump’s health secretary, Robert F Kennedy Jr, to resign, after recent chaos across US health agencies.In an op-ed published in the New York Times on Saturday, the Vermont senator accused Kennedy of “endangering the health of the American people now and into the future”, adding: “He must resign.” Continue reading...

clusters.title: New York City declares Harlem legionnaire’s disease outbreak over
clusters.neutral_headline: New York City declares Harlem legionnaires' outbreak over

items.title: New York City declares Harlem legionnaire’s disease outbreak over
items.standfirst: A hospital’s cooling tower was harboring bacteria as seven people died and 90 were hospitalized over three weeksNew York City has declared the deadly legionnaires’ disease outbreak in central Harlem over, nearly three weeks since it began.On Friday, city health officials announced that there have been no new cases among residents who live or work in the area since 9 August. As of Friday, there have been 114 cases of legionnaires’ disease, with 90 people hospitalized – six of those remaining in hospital – and seven deaths. Continue reading...
items.content: A hospital’s cooling tower was harboring bacteria as seven people died and 90 were hospitalized over three weeksNew York City has declared the deadly legionnaires’ disease outbreak in central Harlem over, nearly three weeks since it began.On Friday, city health officials announced that there have been no new cases among residents who live or work in the area since 9 August. As of Friday, there have been 114 cases of legionnaires’ disease, with 90 people hospitalized – six of those remaining in hospital – and seven deaths. Continue reading...

ai_summary: New York City ended the Harlem legionnaires' disease outbreak.
The outbreak began nearly three weeks prior to the announcement.
No new cases have occurred since August 9th in the area.
114 cases of legionnaires' disease were reported in total.
Seven deaths and 90 hospitalizations resulted from the outbreak.

items.title: Celebrity chef Gordon Ramsay undergoes treatment to remove skin cancer
items.standfirst: Ramsay, 58, has posted thanks on social media to ‘incredible’ health workers and urged followers to remember their sun protectionThe celebrity chef Gordon Ramsay has said he has undergone treatment to remove skin cancer, thanking “incredible” health workers for their efforts and urging fans to remember to wear sun protection.Ramsay, 58, said he had basal cell carcinoma, a non-melanoma form of skin cancer, removed, in a post on Instagram. A picture showed dressings below his ear where the cancer had been removed. Continue reading...

A picture showed dressings below his ear where the cancer had been removed. Continue reading...

clusters.title: A report tied Iowa’s water pollution to agriculture. Then the money to promote it mysteriously disappeared
clusters.neutral_headline: Funding removed after Iowa water pollution study

items.title: A report tied Iowa’s water pollution to agriculture. Then the money to promote it mysteriously disappeared
items.standfirst: Roughly $400,000 in the $1m budget was for public awareness – but those funds were recently ‘zeroed out’When a team of scientists embarked two years ago on a $1m landmark study of Iowa’s persistent water-quality problems, they knew that the findings would be important to share. High cancer rates amid the state’s inability to stem the tide of pollutants flowing into rivers and lakes was a growing public concern.But now, after the completed study pointed to agricultural pollution as a significant source of the key US farm state’s water problems, public officials have quietly stripped funding from plans to promote the study findings, according to sources involved in the project. Continue reading...
items.content: Roughly $400,000 in the $1m budget was for public awareness – but those funds were recently ‘zeroed out’When a team of scientists embarked two years ago on a $1m landmark study of Iowa’s persistent water-quality problems, they knew that the findings would be important to share. High cancer rates amid the state’s inability to stem the tide of pollutants flowing into rivers and lakes was a growing public concern.But now, after the completed study pointed to agricultural pollution as a significant source of the key US farm state’s water problems, public officials have quietly stripped funding from plans to promote the study findings, according to sources involved in the project. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A study linked Iowa's water pollution to agriculture.
Funds for promoting the study were removed.
The study cost $1 million and took two years.
High cancer rates are a concern in Iowa.
The study identified agricultural pollution as a source.

clusters.title: New drug hailed as ‘gamechanger’ in tackling stubbornly high blood pressure
clusters.neutral_headline: New drug shows promise for high blood pressure treatment

items.title: New drug hailed as ‘gamechanger’ in tackling stubbornly high blood pressure
items.standfirst: Trials of baxdrostat have produced ‘exciting’ results for people whose hypertension has proved difficult to controlDoctors are hailing a new pill for patients with high blood pressure resistant to existing medication as a “gamechanger” and a “triumph of science”.Globally, more than 1.3 billion people have hypertension. In half of them, their high blood pressure is uncontrolled or resistant to existing treatments. They face a much higher risk of heart attack, stroke, kidney disease and early death. Continue reading...
items.content: Trials of baxdrostat have produced ‘exciting’ results for people whose hypertension has proved difficult to controlDoctors are hailing a new pill for patients with high blood pressure resistant to existing medication as a “gamechanger” and a “triumph of science”.Globally, more than 1.3 billion people have hypertension. In half of them, their high blood pressure is uncontrolled or resistant to existing treatments. They face a much higher risk of heart attack, stroke, kidney disease and early death. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A new drug, baxdrostat, is showing positive results.
The drug is for patients with difficult-to-control hypertension.
Doctors call it a "gamechanger" and "triumph of science".
Over 1.3 billion people globally have hypertension.
Half of those have uncontrolled or resistant high blood pressure.

clusters.neutral_headline: Experts warn of rising AI use for mental health support

items.title: ‘Sliding into an abyss’: experts warn over rising use of AI for mental health support
items.standfirst: Therapists say they are seeing negative impacts of people increasingly turning to AI chatbots for helpVulnerable people turning to AI chatbots instead of professional therapists for mental health support could be “sliding into a dangerous abyss”, psychotherapists have warned.Psychotherapists and psychiatristssaid they were increasingly seeing negative impacts of AI chatbots being used for mental health, such as fostering emotional dependence, exacerbating anxiety symptoms, self-diagnosis, or amplifying delusional thought patterns, dark thoughts and suicide ideation. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: Exercise and therapy can mend a broken heart, study suggests
clusters.neutral_headline: Exercise and therapy can mend a broken heart, study suggests

items.title: Exercise and therapy can mend a broken heart, study suggests
items.standfirst: Takotsubo syndrome can lead to heart failure and early death. But doctors now believe it can be treatedDoctors may have discovered the secret to mending a broken heart in a world-first clinical trial.Hundreds of thousands of people worldwide are living with takotsubo cardiomyopathy, known as broken heart syndrome, which causes the heart muscle to change shape and suddenly weaken. It is usually triggered by severe emotional or physical stress, such as losing a loved one. Continue reading...
items.content: Takotsubo syndrome can lead to heart failure and early death. But doctors now believe it can be treatedDoctors may have discovered the secret to mending a broken heart in a world-first clinical trial.Hundreds of thousands of people worldwide are living with takotsubo cardiomyopathy, known as broken heart syndrome, which causes the heart muscle to change shape and suddenly weaken. It is usually triggered by severe emotional or physical stress, such as losing a loved one. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: MHRA is cracking down on unlicensed anti-wrinkle products after spate of botulism cases in EnglandSellers of fake Botox jabs could be jailed for up to two years, the UK’s medicine watchdog has warned, as it increases efforts to track down those flouting the law.The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) says it is cracking down on the trade of unlicensed botulinum toxin products after a spate of botulism cases across England thought to be linked to them. Continue reading...

clusters.title: RFK Jr continues to make dubious health claims as CDC roils under his leadership
clusters.neutral_headline: RFK Jr Makes Dubious Health Claims Amid CDC Leadership Changes

items.title: RFK Jr continues to make dubious health claims as CDC roils under his leadership
items.standfirst: As leaders at Centers for Disease Control quit after director’s firing, Kennedy stokes controversy with pet theoriesIn a week of chaos at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Donald Trump’s health secretary, Robert F Kennedy Jr, has continued to make questionable medical and health claims – and has been slammed for them by experts and lawmakers alike.In recent days, Kennedy has been facing increasing calls for his resignation following the Trump administration’s firing of the CDC director, Susan Monarez, which in turn prompted four other top officials to quit the agency. The chaos across US health agencies also comes as Kennedy released a slew of controversial and contradictory rules surrounding Covid-19 vaccines. Continue reading...
items.content: As leaders at Centers for Disease Control quit after director’s firing, Kennedy stokes controversy with pet theoriesIn a week of chaos at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Donald Trump’s health secretary, Robert F Kennedy Jr, has continued to make questionable medical and health claims – and has been slammed for them by experts and lawmakers alike.In recent days, Kennedy has been facing increasing calls for his resignation following the Trump administration’s firing of the CDC director, Susan Monarez, which in turn prompted four other top officials to quit the agency. The chaos across US health agencies also comes as Kennedy released a slew of controversial and contradictory rules surrounding Covid-19 vaccines. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Robert F Kennedy Jr continues making questionable medical claims, facing criticism from experts and lawmakers.
The CDC director's firing by the Trump administration prompted resignations of four other top officials.
Kennedy released controversial and contradictory rules regarding Covid-19 vaccines recently.
Calls for Kennedy's resignation have increased amid the turmoil at the CDC.
The chaos at US health agencies is ongoing as Kennedy continues to make claims.

clusters.title: Potassium-rich diet may cut risk of heart failure by 24%, study suggests
clusters.neutral_headline: Potassium-Rich Diet Linked to Reduced Heart Failure Risk

items.title: Potassium-rich diet may cut risk of heart failure by 24%, study suggests
items.standfirst: Eating foods such as avocados, bananas and spinach linked to lower risk of heart conditions, hospitalisation or deathEating foods rich in potassium, such as avocados, bananas and spinach, could reduce your risk of heart conditions, hospitalisation and death by 24%, a study suggests.Previous research has shown that cutting out salt from meals can slash your risk of heart problems. Reducing the number of meals to which you add salt or ditching it altogether can make a huge difference to your heart health. Continue reading...
items.content: Eating foods such as avocados, bananas and spinach linked to lower risk of heart conditions, hospitalisation or deathEating foods rich in potassium, such as avocados, bananas and spinach, could reduce your risk of heart conditions, hospitalisation and death by 24%, a study suggests.Previous research has shown that cutting out salt from meals can slash your risk of heart problems. Reducing the number of meals to which you add salt or ditching it altogether can make a huge difference to your heart health. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A study suggests a potassium-rich diet may reduce heart failure risk by 24%.
Foods like avocados, bananas, and spinach are high in potassium.
The study links potassium intake to lower risk of heart conditions, hospitalizations, and death.
Previous research showed reducing salt intake can lower heart problem risk.
Limiting or eliminating added salt can significantly improve heart health.
